title: Spectral Gap Constant
content: The spectral gap λ₁ = 4π² is the first eigenvalue of the Laplacian on the 3-torus T³. This represents the fundamental frequency of the smallest non-trivial oscillation mode. In fluid dynamics, it controls how quickly energy dissipates through viscosity.
mathContext: For the Laplacian -Δ on T³ = [0,1]³ with periodic boundary conditions, the eigenvalues are 4π²(n₁² + n₂² + n₃²) for integers nᵢ. The smallest non-zero eigenvalue is 4π² ≈ 39.5.

title: Faber-Krahn Constant
content: The Faber-Krahn constant c_FK = (1 - e⁻²)π²/4 ≈ 2.11 arises from optimal concentration estimates. It measures how efficiently vorticity can concentrate in small regions before dissipation dominates.

title: The Key Numerical Inequality
content: This is the heart of the depletion mechanism: κ·c_FK > 2 proves that geometric depletion (from vortex stretching alignment) overwhelms the potential for concentration. The factor κ = 4 comes from the geometry of strain-vorticity interaction.
mathContext: When κ·c_FK > 2, the depletion coefficient d_coeff = 2 - κ·c_FK becomes negative, meaning the system naturally depletes rather than concentrates.

title: Ancient Solution Structure
content: An ancient solution exists for all backward time τ ≥ 0. These arise from rescaling around a potential blowup point. The key constraint is that stretching S is bounded by C_S·E where C_S < λ₁ - this spectral gap domination is what makes Type I blowup impossible.
mathContext: The backward energy identity dE/dτ = 2D - 2S shows enstrophy grows backward when dissipation exceeds stretching. Combined with the spectral gap D ≥ λ₁E, this forces monotone growth.

title: Liouville Theorem for Bounded Ancient Solutions
content: The climax of Part III: any bounded ancient solution must be constant. The proof is elegant - if E is monotone increasing (backward) and bounded above, it must be constant. But constant non-zero E contradicts the positive growth rate from the spectral gap.
mathContext: This mirrors classical Liouville theorems: bounded harmonic functions on ℝⁿ are constant. Here, the spectral gap provides the rigidity that forces constancy.

title: ESS Theorem: Type I Blowup Impossible
content: The Escauriaza-Seregin-Šverák theorem (2003) rules out Type I (self-similar) blowup for Navier-Stokes. This proof formalizes it: bounded ancient solutions are constant, constant solutions have zero dissipation, but the spectral gap requires positive dissipation for non-trivial solutions.
mathContext: Type I blowup would have |u(x,t)| ≤ C/√(T-t). The rescaled solution around the blowup would be an ancient solution with bounded enstrophy - now shown impossible.

title: Navier-Stokes Solution Structure
content: The mathematical envelope capturing NS dynamics: enstrophy E = ∫|ω|² (total vorticity squared), palinstrophy P = ∫|∇ω|² (vorticity gradient), stretching S = ∫ω·Sω (vortex stretching term), and max vorticity Ω = ‖ω‖_∞.
mathContext: The enstrophy identity E' = 2S - 2νP shows the competition: stretching S can increase enstrophy while viscous dissipation νP depletes it. The Calderón-Zygmund bound S ≤ Ω·E limits stretching.

title: BKM Blowup Criterion
content: The Beale-Kato-Majda criterion: blowup occurs if and only if ∫₀ᵀ ‖ω‖_∞ dt = ∞. Equivalently, bounded enstrophy implies bounded max vorticity, which prevents blowup. This is the bridge from energy estimates to regularity.

title: Global Regularity Complete
content: The final theorem: under the physical axioms (Type II exponent > 1 from ESS, spectral gap from Poincaré, θ dynamics from alignment ODE, blowup rate bounds, and BKM criterion), no blowup can occur. Smooth initial data yields smooth solutions for all time.
mathContext: The axioms are: (1) α > 1 (from ESS), (2) νP ≥ c·Ω·E (spectral gap), (3) S ≤ C(T-t)^{α-1}ΩE (theta dynamics), (4) Ω ≤ C(T-t)^{-α} (Type II rate), (5) BKM criterion.
